greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of 3's in the last section of the set of partitions of n.
comment: Also number of 3's in all partitions of n that do not contain 1 as a part.
Also 0 together with the first differences of A024787. - _Omar E. Pol_, Nov 13 2011
a(n) is the number of partitions of n having fewer 1s than 2s; e.g., a(7) counts these 3 partitions: [5, 2], [3, 2, 2], [2, 2, 2, 1]. - _Clark Kimberling_, Mar 31 2014
The last section of the set of partitions of n is also the n-th section of the set of partitions of any integer >= n. - _Omar E. Pol_, Apr 07 2014
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
formula: It appears that A000041(n) = a(n+1) + a(n+2) + a(n+3), n >= 0. - _Omar E. Pol_, Feb 04 2012
Conjecture: a(n) ~ A000041(n)/3 ~ exp(Pi*sqrt(2*n/3)) / (12*sqrt(3)*n). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jan 03 2019
example: In the last section of the set of partitions of 7 the difference between the sum of the third column and the sum of the fourth column is 5 - 3 = 2 equaling the number of 3's, so a(7) = 2 (see also A024787).
maple: b:= proc(n, i) option remember; local g, h;
mathematica: z = 60; f[n_] := f[n] = IntegerPartitions[n]; t1 = Table[Count[f[n], p_ /; Count[p, 1] < Count[p, 2]], {n, 0, z}] (* _Clark Kimberling_, Mar 31 2014 *)
program: (Sage) A182713 = lambda n: sum(list(p).count(3) for p in Partitions(n) if 1 not in p) # _D. S. McNeil_, Nov 29 2010
results.author: _Omar E. Pol_, Nov 28 2010
